analysis: Candidiasis can be treated with various antifungal agents, and the effectiveness of these agents can vary based on their formulation and route of administration. Among the options provided, Itraconazole (opd) and Ketoconazole (opb) are both effective when taken orally. Itraconazole is often preferred due to its broader antifungal spectrum and better safety profile compared to Ketoconazole, which has notable side effects and potential drug interactions that limit its use. Clotrimazole (opc) and Micanozole (opa) are primarily used topically and are not effective for oral treatment of candidiasis. Therefore, while both Itraconazole and Ketoconazole are orally effective, Itraconazole is the more commonly recommended first-line treatment for candidiasis. Thus, the best choice is Itraconazole.
